Description: Saint-Gobain Containers Inc. of Muncie, Ind., agreed, in a consent decree filed in federal court in Seattle, to install pollution control equipment at an estimated cost of $112 million to reduce emissions of NOx, SO2 and PM by approximately 6,000 tons each year. The settlement covered 15 plants in 13 states. Two of the 15 plants had been closed by Saint-Gobain for independent business reasons. In addition, as part of the settlement, Saint-Gobain agreed to pay a $2.25 million civil penalty to resolve its alleged violations of the Clean Air Act's new source review regulations.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department
Info Source: http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/united-states-announces-two-major-clean-air-act-new-source-review-settlements-28-industrial

Description: As part of a Clean Air Act settlement, Saint-Gobain Containers, Inc. of Muncie, Indiana agreed to reduce emissions through the installation of approximately $6.6 million worth of new equipment, pay a civil penalty of $929,000 and spend $1.2 million for an environmental project that will also reduce emissions.
Agency: Justice Department Environment and Natural Resources Division
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2005/April/05_enrd_203.htm

Description: As part of ongoing federal and state efforts to restore Puget Sound, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency is announcing enforcement actions against three Seattle-area companies for discharging industrial stormwater to Puget Sound waterways in violation of the Clean Water Act. In addition to the companies committing to manage stormwater more diligently at their facilities in the future, they agreed to pay a combined total of $163,500 in penalties.
Info Source: https://archive.epa.gov/epapages/newsroom_archive/newsreleases/27af5f2d9d9943a085257cca0075e7b9.html
FOIA101
Notes: Source document obtained through a Freedom of Information Act request to the agency.

Description: On May 5, 2004, a Notice of Violation and Proposed Imposition of Civil Penalty in the amount of $7,500 was issued for a Severity Level III violation involving the failure to secure from unauthorized removal and failure to control and maintain constant surveillance of licensed material (150 millicuries of americium-241 in a thickness gauge, a generally-licensed device) in a controlled area, resulting in the loss of the gauge. Although the civil penalty would have been fully mitigated based on the normal civil penalty assessment process, a base civil penalty was assessed in accordance with Section VII.A.1.g of the Enforcement Policy to reflect the significance of maintaining control of licensed material.
Info Source: https://www.nrc.gov/docs/ML0412/ML041260425.pdf

Description: Saint-Gobain agreed to pay $1.1 million to ten states to resolve alleged violations of the Clean Air Act's new source review regulations. This was part of a larger $114 million settlement involving the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-saint-gobain-containers-inc
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/united-states-announces-two-major-clean-air-act-new-source-review-settlements-28-industrial
Portage County Manufacturer to Pay Penalty for Violating Ohio's Air Pollution Control Laws, US States News, December 20, 2005 (via Nexis).

Description: Saint-Gobain agreed to pay an estimated $20-25 million to extend municipal water lines to 245 homes in Bennington whose drinking water wells were contaminated with the dangerous chemical PFOA.
Info Source: https://ago.vermont.gov/blog/2019/04/10/state-reaches-agreement-with-saint-gobain-company-agrees-to-fund-waterline-extensions-and-other-remediation-measures-on-benningtons-east-side/

Description: Saint-Gobain Performance Plastics, Honeywell International and 3M agreed to pay a total of $65.25 million to settle litigation alleging they were responsible for contamination of the water supply of Hoosick Falls, New York with firefighting foam containing perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA), also known as a forever chemical. The parties did not disclose how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided evenly among them.
Private Litigation Case Title: Baker et al v. Saint-Gobain Performance Plastics Corp. et al
Info Source: https://www.law360.com/articles/1462104/-65m-new-york-forever-chemical-water-suit-gets-final-ok
https://edocpub.epa.ohio.gov/publicportal/ViewDocument.aspx?docid=1628934
